title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: CareDensity package small R package can used mainly calculate various measures Care Density (Pollack et al. 2013, Engels et al. 2024) Coordination Care Indices (Jee & Cabana 2006). vignette show simple examples index give explanations mean.

title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: package currently available CRAN, developmental version can installed github, using following code:

title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: care density first proposed Pollack et al. (2013). measure supposed measure closely “care team” patient (providers / medical doctors contact ) connected. indirect measure closely two providers work together, number patients shared providers used. Therefore, order calculate care density, information need patient visited provider. information can considered “patient-sharing network” used multiple studies already (DuGoff et al. 2018, Landon et al. 2012). Formally, care density defined : \[C_p = \frac{\sum_{= 1}^m w_{p, j}}{n_p (n_p - 1)/2},\] \(n_p\) number providers patient visited, \(m\) defined number possible combinations length two \(w_{p, j}\) number patients pair provider sharing.

title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: Suppose following data 5 patients (denoted numbers) 3 providers visited (denoted uppercase letters): Since connections patients providers connections provider providers patients patients, can considered bipartite graph. can visualize graph using igraph package:  Consider patient number 1 graph. can see patient visited 3 different providers (\(\), \(B\) \(C\)). Therefore, \(n_p\) equal 3 patient. weights? gain better understanding, can project graph provider-centric network, providers included:  graph can see exactly provider shared many patients. patient 1 care density : \[C_1 = \frac{1 + 1 + 3}{3 (3 - 1)/2} \approx 1.6667.\] easy calculate single patient small network, unfeasible hand large network multiple patients. care_density() function can used automatically perform step taken hand . need supply original data : can see gets result patient 1 also outputs care density patients. Since patient 4 5 visited one provider, care density undefined thus denoted NA.
code: library(CareDensity) library(igraph) library(data.table) library(MatrixExtra)  set.seed(3431)  # some arbitrary patient-provider contact data data <- data.frame(PatID=c("1", "1", "1", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5"),                    ArztID=c("A", "C", "D", "A", "D", "A", "D", "D", "C")) data #>   PatID ArztID #> 1     1      A #> 2     1      C #> 3     1      D #> 4     2      A #> 5     2      D #> 6     3      A #> 7     3      D #> 8     4      D #> 9     5      C # create graph g <- graph_from_data_frame(data, directed=FALSE)  # add type V(g)$type <- bipartite_mapping(g)$type  # change some things for better plots V(g)$color <- ifelse(V(g)$type, "salmon", "lightblue") V(g)$shape <- ifelse(V(g)$type, "square", "circle") E(g)$color <- "lightgray"  plot(g, vertex.label.cex=0.8, vertex.label.color="black") # project to provider mode mat <- project_to_one_mode(g, mode="cols")  # make it an igraph object again g_provider <- graph_from_adjacency_matrix(mat, mode="upper", weighted=TRUE, diag=FALSE)  # plot it plot(g_provider, edge.label=E(g_provider)$weight, vertex.shape="square",      edge.color="black", vertex.color="salmon",      vertex.label.cex=0.8) care_density(data) #>   PatID sum_weights n care_density #> 1     1           5 3     1.666667 #> 2     2           3 2     3.000000 #> 3     3           3 2     3.000000 #> 4     4          NA 1           NA #> 5     5          NA 1           NA

title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: care density defined Pollack et al. (2014) recently criticed Engels et al. (2024). main point : 1.) care density assumes relationships amount patients shared contribute equally care coordination. therefore consider many patients single provider . 2.) kind relationship also considered classic care density statistic. example, relationships psychiatrists general providers may less important general provider - general provider relationships. 3.) importance specific relationships may vary different outcomes different patient population, therefore also considered classic care density measure Pollack et al. (2024). Engels et al. (2024) instead propose modified version care density, call fragmented care density. main idea stratify sum term classic care density multiple provider-relationship specific sums. \[C_p = \sum_{j = 1}^{k} \frac{s_j}{n_p(n_p - 1) /2},\] \(k\) defined : \[k = {l \choose 2} + l,\] \(l\) number provider types. example, three different provider types (psychiatrist, general provider, ), 6 different relationships. easy see formulation equivalent one given Pollack et al. (2013). new proposal weight different connection types differently. fragmented care density proposed Engels et al. (2024) given : \[FC_p = \sum_{j = 1}^{k} w_j \frac{s_j}{n_p(n_p - 1) /2}.\] \(w_j\) connection specific weights. Engels et al. (2024) propose use regression models estimate weights. explained little detail .

title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: Consider example dataset defined . Suppose, however, provider known either general practitioner psychiatrist. following data.frame defines type provider example: Since two different kinds providers, 3 possible provider connections: GP - GP GP - Psychiatrist Psychiatrist - Psychiatrist can safely omit “Psychiatrist - GP” connection type, always dealing undirected connections, means order appearance make difference. Now can use fragmented_care_density() function follows: setting by_connection TRUE telling function directly calculate fragmented care density us, instead return sum weights care densities per connection type patient. dataset can see patient 1 two different kinds provider connections among network. sum care densities patient connection types, get classic care density. calculate actual fragmented care density patient, need supply weights connection type. can constructing data.frame looks like : , set weights 1. Therefore, now call fragmented_care_density() function (time without using by_connection argument): get results using simple care_density() function. However, use different weights connection type: call function : obtain different results. Note never matters patients 4 5, one provider connection, resulting NA values matter weights.
code: d_type <- data.frame(ID=c("A", "C", "D"),                      Type=c("GP", "GP", "Psychiatrist")) d_type #>   ID         Type #> 1  A           GP #> 2  C           GP #> 3  D Psychiatrist fragmented_care_density(data, weights=NULL, type=d_type, by_connection=TRUE) #>   PatID        connection sum_weights n care_density #> 1     1           GP - GP           1 3    0.3333333 #> 2     1 Psychiatrist - GP           4 3    1.3333333 #> 3     2 Psychiatrist - GP           3 2    3.0000000 #> 4     3 Psychiatrist - GP           3 2    3.0000000 #> 5     4              <NA>          NA 1           NA #> 6     5              <NA>          NA 1           NA d_weights <- data.frame(from=c("GP", "GP", "Psychiatrist"),                         to=c("GP", "Psychiatrist", "Psychiatrist"),                         weight=c(1, 1, 1)) d_weights #>           from           to weight #> 1           GP           GP      1 #> 2           GP Psychiatrist      1 #> 3 Psychiatrist Psychiatrist      1 fragmented_care_density(data, weights=d_weights, type=d_type) #>   PatID fragmented_care_density #> 1     1                1.666667 #> 2     2                3.000000 #> 3     3                3.000000 #> 4     4                      NA #> 5     5                      NA d_weights <- data.frame(from=c("GP", "GP", "Psychiatrist"),                         to=c("GP", "Psychiatrist", "Psychiatrist"),                         weight=c(1.1, 0.5, 1.3)) d_weights #>           from           to weight #> 1           GP           GP    1.1 #> 2           GP Psychiatrist    0.5 #> 3 Psychiatrist Psychiatrist    1.3 fragmented_care_density(data, weights=d_weights, type=d_type) #>   PatID fragmented_care_density #> 1     1                1.033333 #> 2     2                1.500000 #> 3     3                1.500000 #> 4     4                      NA #> 5     5                      NA

title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: example , used arbitrary weights showcase functionality fragmented_care_density() function. reality like use sensible weights instead. Engels et al. (2024) recommend using regression models obtain relevant weights. article, use logistic regression model predict binary outcome, given presence connection type covariates. illustrate approach without use covariates. Suppose addition data (patient-provider relationships) type (provider types) also patient level information binary outcome interest \(Y\). Suppose data: First, obtain data connection sums (\(s_j\)) per connection type: binarize weights 0 / 1. least one connection present, considered 1, otherwise 0: Next, transform information long-format using dcast() function data.table package: Afterwards can merge outcome data dataset: Now can finally fit regression model, using outcome dependent variable connection-type dummies independent variables: estimated coefficients associated connection type may now used weights. Note example weights don’t make sense due (1) low sample size, (2) small network (3) data completely made underlying true relationships. general procedure, however, work real data.
code: d_outcome <- data.frame(PatID=c("1", "2", "3", "4", "5"),                         Y=c(0, 0, 1, 1, 0)) d_outcome #>   PatID Y #> 1     1 0 #> 2     2 0 #> 3     3 1 #> 4     4 1 #> 5     5 0 d_consum <- fragmented_care_density(data, weights=NULL, type=d_type, by_connection=TRUE) d_consum$sum_weights <- fifelse(d_consum$sum_weights > 0, 1, 0) d_consum <- dcast(as.data.table(d_consum), PatID ~ connection,                   value.var="sum_weights", fill=0) d_consum$`NA` <- NULL d_outcome <- merge(d_consum, d_outcome, by="PatID") mod <- glm(Y ~ `GP - GP` + `Psychiatrist - GP`, data=d_outcome, family="binomial") summary(mod) #>  #> Call: #> glm(formula = Y ~ `GP - GP` + `Psychiatrist - GP`, family = "binomial",  #>     data = d_outcome) #>  #> Coefficients: #>                       Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) #> (Intercept)         -1.256e-16  1.414e+00   0.000    1.000 #> `GP - GP`           -1.857e+01  6.523e+03  -0.003    0.998 #> `Psychiatrist - GP`  0.000e+00  2.000e+00   0.000    1.000 #>  #> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) #>  #>     Null deviance: 6.7301  on 4  degrees of freedom #> Residual deviance: 5.5452  on 2  degrees of freedom #> AIC: 11.545 #>  #> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 17

title: Calculating the Care Density and Fragmented Care Density in R
text: DuGoff, Eva H., Sara Fernandes-Taylor, Gary E. Weissman, Joseph H. Huntley, Craig Evan Pollack. (2018). “Scoping Review Patient-Sharing Network Studies Using Administrative Data”. Translational Behavioral Medicine 8 (4), pp. 598-625. Engels, Alexander, Claudia Konnopka, Espen Henken, Martin Härter, Hans-Helmut König. (2024). “Flexible Approach Measure Care Coordination Based Patient-Sharing Networks”. BMC Medical Research Methodology 24 (1), pp. 1-12. Jee, Sandra H., Michael D. Cabana. (2006). “Indices Continuity Care: Systematic Review Literature”. Medical Care Research Review 63 (2), pp. 158-188. Landon, Bruce E., Nancy L. Keating, Michael L. Barnett, Jukka-Pekka Onnela, Sudeshna Paul, . James O’Malley, Thomas Keegan, Nicholas . Christakis. (2012). “Variation Patient-Sharing Networks Physicians Across United States”. JAMA 308 (3): pp. 265-273. Pollack, Craig Evan, Gary E. Weissman, Klaus W. Lemke, Peter S. Hussey, Jonathan P. Weiner. (2013). “Patient Sharing Among Physicians Costs Care: Network Analytic Approach Care Coordination Using Claims Data”. Journal General Internal Medicine 28 (3), pp. 459-465.

what: Calculate the Care Density or Fragmented Care Density given a Patient-Sharing Network
title: Calculate the Care Density or Fragmented Care Density given a Patient-Sharing Network
text: Author: Robin Denz

title: Calculate the Care Density or Fragmented Care Density given a Patient-Sharing Network
text: CareDensity small R-Package can used calculate care density index fragemented care density.

title: Calculate the Care Density or Fragmented Care Density given a Patient-Sharing Network
text: developmental version package may installed github using remotes R-Package:

title: Calculate the Care Density or Fragmented Care Density given a Patient-Sharing Network
text: encounter bugs specific feature requests, please file Issue.

what: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
title: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
text: function calculates classic Care Density Index defined Pollack et al. (2013) patient supplied dataset. Works well large patient-sharing networks.

title: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
text: data data.frame like object containing exactly two columns. One include patient IDs one provider IDs. row denote one patient-provider contact. Multiple contacts (rows) allowed effect outcome. patient provider IDs unique, means one ID may rows. pat_col Specifies column data includes patient IDs. first column contains patient IDs kept 1, second column contains patient IDs set 2. data_frame Set argument TRUE return data.frame instead data.table format used hood.

title: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
text: Care Density (\(C_p\)) "patient-level measure quantifies amount patient-sharing among providers" (DuGoff et al. 2018). Higher care densities posited reflect greater connections among patients "care team". Formally, defined : $$C_p = \frac{\sum_{= 1}^m w_{p, j}}{n_p (n_p - 1)/2}$$ \(n_p\) number providers patient visited, \(m\) defined number possible combinations length two \(w_{p, j}\) number patients pair provider sharing. example given explained thoroughly vignette package. hood, function uses igraph package construct patient-sharing network provided data calculate weights. uses data.table package efficiently calculate care densities resulting edge list weights.

title: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
text: Returns single data.frame (data.table) containing sum weights ("sum_weights"), number providers seen patient ("n") calculated Care Density ("care_density").

title: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
text: Pollack, Craig Evan, Gary E. Weissman, Klaus W. Lemke, Peter S. Hussey, Jonathan P. Weiner. (2013). "Patient Sharing Among Physicians Costs Care: Network Analytic Approach Care Coordination Using Claims Data". Journal General Internal Medicine 28 (3), pp. 459-465. DuGoff, Eva H., Sara Fernandes-Taylor, Gary E. Weissman, Joseph H. Huntley, Craig Evan Pollack. (2018). "Scoping Review Patient-Sharing Network Studies Using Administrative Data". Translational Behavioral Medicine 8 (4), pp. 598-625.

title: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
text: Robin Denz

title: Calculate the Care Density for all Patients — care_density
code: library(CareDensity) library(data.table) library(igraph) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘igraph’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     decompose, spectrum #> The following object is masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     union  # some arbitrary patient-provider contact data data <- data.frame(PatID=c("1", "1", "1", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5"),                    ArztID=c("A", "C", "D", "A", "D", "A", "D", "D", "C"))                     # calculate the care densities care_density(data) #>   PatID sum_weights n care_density #> 1     1           5 3     1.666667 #> 2     2           3 2     3.000000 #> 3     3           3 2     3.000000 #> 4     4          NA 1           NA #> 5     5          NA 1           NA

what: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
text: function calculates Fragmented Care Density Index defined Engels et al. (2024) patient supplied dataset. Works well large patient-sharing networks.

title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
code: fragmented_care_density(data, pat_col=1, weights, type,                         by_connection=FALSE, data_frame=TRUE)

title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
text: data data.frame like object containing exactly two columns. One include patient IDs one provider IDs. row denote one patient-provider contact. Multiple contacts (rows) allowed effect outcome. patient provider IDs unique, means one ID may rows. pat_col Specifies column data includes patient IDs. first column contains patient IDs kept 1, second column contains patient IDs set 2. weights data.frame containing three columns called "" (character), "" (character) "weight" (numeric). first two columns contain types providers, thus definining different provider connections. possible non-redundant connections need specified way. "weight" column include weight associated connection. using by_connection=TRUE argument can set NULL, needed . See examples information. type data.frame containing two columns called "ID" (containing provider IDs) "Type" (containing type provider). columns character vectors. by_connection Either TRUE FALSE (default). TRUE function returns person connection-specific sums weights simple care densities instead returning fragmented care density directly. may useful estimate weights weights argument. data_frame Set argument TRUE return data.frame instead data.table format used hood.

title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
text: Fragmented Care Density extension classic Care Density (see care_density) proposed Engels et al. (2024). also measure care coordination, allows lot flexibility using different weights different provider-type connections. example, may make sense weight amount patients shared two general providers differently amount patients shared general provider specialist. Formally, fragmented care density defined : $$FC_p = \sum_{j = 1}^{k} w_j \frac{s_j}{n_p(n_p - 1) /2},$$ \(n_p\) number different providers patient \(p\) visited \(w_j\) connection specific weights. \(k\) defined : $$k = {l \choose 2} + l,$$ \(l\) number different provider types. Finally, \(s_j\) sum number patients shared doctors specific connection type. See Engels et al. (2024) information. hood, function uses igraph package construct patient-sharing network provided data calculate weights. uses data.table package efficiently calculate care densities resulting edge list weights.

title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
text: Returns single data.frame (data.table) containing output depending specification by_connection argument. by_connection=FALSE used output includes patient id ("PatID") calculated fragmented care densities ("fragmented_care_density"). by_connection=TRUE used instead, output includes patient id ("PatID"), connection-type ("connection") sum weights ("sum_weights"), number providers seen patient ("n") calculated simple care density ("care_density").

title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
text: Pollack, Craig Evan, Gary E. Weissman, Klaus W. Lemke, Peter S. Hussey, Jonathan P. Weiner. (2013). "Patient Sharing Among Physicians Costs Care: Network Analytic Approach Care Coordination Using Claims Data". Journal General Internal Medicine 28 (3), pp. 459-465. Engels, Alexander, Claudia Konnopka, Espen Henken, Martin Härter, Hans-Helmut König. (2024). "Flexible Approach Measure Care Coordination Based Patient-Sharing Networks". BMC Medical Research Methodology 24 (1), pp. 1-12.

title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
text: Robin Denz

title: Calculate the Fragmented Care Density for all Patients — fragmented_care_density
code: library(CareDensity) library(data.table) library(igraph)  # some arbitrary patient-provider contact data data <- data.frame(PatID=c("1", "1", "1", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5"),                    ArztID=c("A", "C", "D", "A", "D", "A", "D", "D", "C"))  # defining the provider types d_type <- data.frame(ID=c("A", "C", "D"),                      Type=c("GP", "GP", "Psychiatrist"))                       # defining the connection-specific weights d_weights <- data.frame(from=c("GP", "GP", "Psychiatrist"),                         to=c("GP", "Psychiatrist", "Psychiatrist"),                         weight=c(1.1, 0.8, 1.3))  # calculate the fragmented care densities fragmented_care_density(data, type=d_type, weights=d_weights) #>   PatID fragmented_care_density #> 1     1                1.433333 #> 2     2                2.400000 #> 3     3                2.400000 #> 4     4                      NA #> 5     5                      NA  # calculate only the connection-specific sums and care-densities per patient # NOTE: "weights" can be set to NULL here because they won't be used fragmented_care_density(data, type=d_type, weights=NULL, by_connection=TRUE) #>   PatID        connection sum_weights n care_density #> 1     1           GP - GP           1 3    0.3333333 #> 2     1 Psychiatrist - GP           4 3    1.3333333 #> 3     2 Psychiatrist - GP           3 2    3.0000000 #> 4     3 Psychiatrist - GP           3 2    3.0000000 #> 5     4              <NA>          NA 1           NA #> 6     5              <NA>          NA 1           NA

what: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
title: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
text: function takes bipartite network created using igraph package returns adjacency matrix one underlying modes. directly allowing sparse matrices faster RAM efficient available versions.

title: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
text: g igraph object two different node types, defining bipartite graph. mode Either "rows" "cols", defining mode calculated. sparse Whether use sparse matrix representations . Must either TRUE FALSE.

title: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
text: bipartite graph connections two types nodes. example, one type node may providers type may patients. health-care databases usually see patient visited providers, see direct links providers patients. type graph can projected two subgraphs. One includes providers one includes patients. function efficiently creates adjacency matrices projections. resulting adjacency matrix symmetric square matrix contains number shared patients (provider level graphs) number shared providers (patient level graph). See examples .

title: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
text: Returns sparse adjacency matrix specified mode.

title: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
text: Landon, Bruce E., Nancy L. Keating, Michael L. Barnett, Jukka-Pekka Onnela, Sudeshna Paul, . James O’Malley, Thomas Keegan, Nicholas . Christakis. (2012). "Variation Patient-Sharing Networks Physicians Across United States". JAMA 308 (3): 265–73.

title: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
text: Robin Denz

title: Project a Bipartite-Network to a Single Mode — project_to_one_mode
code: library(CareDensity) library(igraph)  # some arbitrary patient-provider contact data data <- data.frame(PatID=c("1", "1", "1", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5"),                    ArztID=c("A", "C", "D", "A", "D", "A", "D", "D", "C"))  # create graph g <- graph_from_data_frame(data, directed=FALSE)  # add type V(g)$type <- bipartite_mapping(g)$type  ## NOTE: we use sparse=FALSE here to show the resulting matrix directly, #        but it would be more efficient to keep it at sparse=TRUE # project to patient-level project_to_one_mode(g, mode="rows", sparse=FALSE) #>   1 2 3 4 5 #> 1 0 2 2 1 1 #> 2 2 0 2 1 0 #> 3 2 2 0 1 0 #> 4 1 1 1 0 0 #> 5 1 0 0 0 0  # project to provider-level project_to_one_mode(g, mode="cols", sparse=FALSE) #>   A C D #> A 0 1 3 #> C 1 0 1 #> D 3 1 0

title: CareDensity 0.1.0
text: first release package
